visibility_factors: patchy fog/low clouds overnight (1 mile at ~1 AM)
periods of moderate rain early morning

alert_summary.description: River rises from snow/ice melt plus rain; low-end flood/ice jam concern, not a travel-hazard winter storm headline.

meteorology.overall_conditions_summary: Rockford’s Wed 2026-02-18 setup is a mild, wet rain event—not a Michigan snow/ice day. Temps stay well above freezing (mid 30s to upper 40s), with 0" snow expected. The main impact is a burst of moderate rain centered on the early-morning commute (roughly 4–6 AM, then again near/after 8 AM), which can cause ponding and reduced visibility, but roads should be just wet (not icy). Wind chills during bus time are in the upper 20s (about 27–29°F), far from cold-closure thresholds. Given Michigan’s winter capability and no accumulating snow/ice signal, the snow-day/closure probability is very low (~0–5%); at most, watch for localized minor flooding/standing water in poor-drainage spots and slower bus operations.

similar_weather_patterns.pattern_description: Mid-winter thaw + soaking rain (0.5–1.0 in) with temps hovering 33–40°F around the morning commute: typically a ‘sloppy roads’ setup, not a classic snow day. Closures usually only happen if the rain ends up freezing on untreated back roads/bridges right at bus time or if there’s dense fog/low vis plus standing water issues.

Overnight moderate rain with temps just above freezing at/near daybreak, then drying/temps rising into the 40s by afternoon: most Michigan districts stay open; you might see delays if there’s localized icing on bridges or rural hills.

Warm-day rain event occurring while there is remaining snowpack/river ice (meltwater + rain): can produce localized flooding, ponding, and occasional ice-jam issues, but school closures are uncommon unless roads become impassable in a few low-lying routes.

seasonal_context.typical_conditions_for_date: For mid-February in the Rockford (Kent County/Grand Rapids metro) area, schools are usually fully ‘winter-capable’ and closures are overwhelmingly driven by (1) heavy snow during the 6:00–8:00 AM window, (2) meaningful ice accretion, or (3) blizzard/drifting. A rain-only event with temps in the mid-30s is generally not enough by itself to close schools in West Michigan.
unusual_factors: Forecast is precipitation-heavy for February (around 0.77" liquid) but with no snow expected.
Temperatures sit very close to freezing near the morning commute (mid-30s), which is the main ‘gotcha’ for a flash-freeze on elevated surfaces if temps dip a degree or two lower than forecast.

NWS Hydrologic Outlook indicates ongoing snow/ice melt and rising rivers/possible ice movement—this supports ponding/standing water and isolated trouble spots, but not a widespread closure signal by itself.

local_microclimates: Rural/north-of-town bus routes and low-traffic back roads can glaze first if any brief freezing occurs (especially bridges and overpasses).
Areas near the Rogue River/Grand River system can see ponding in low spots during heavy rain + melt; a few recurrent ‘problem intersections’ can drive a delay decision even when main roads are fine.
If fog thickens near sunrise (high humidity, saturated ground), visibility can drop quickly in river valleys—this tends to influence ‘delay’ decisions more than full closures.
infrastructure_considerations: Kent County/West Michigan road agencies and districts are generally well-equipped; with temps above freezing most of the event, treatment is effective and plowing isn’t the issue.
The deciding window is 6:00–8:00 AM: if surfaces are just wet (not icy) and visibility is decent, districts typically remain open.
location_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Rockford has enough gentle elevation variation that colder pockets and bridge decks can be a couple degrees colder than reported air temps. That matters when the forecast is ~35–36°F: a small downward error can create isolated slick spots.

history.confidence_assessment: Medium confidence: the forecast strongly favors rain (not snow) and above-freezing air temps, which historically produces low closure rates in Michigan. The main uncertainty is a narrow temperature margin near the morning commute—if it verifies 31–33°F instead of 35–36°F on untreated/raised surfaces, the impact can jump from ‘wet’ to ‘patchy ice,’ which is the one pathway to a surprise delay/closure.

safety_recommendations: Primary hazard is a wet-to-near-freezing morning: expect ponding in low spots and reduced braking/turning performance on wet, cold pavement—especially on bridges/overpasses and shaded curves.

Have transportation supervisors monitor for isolated slick spots around 6:00–8:30 AM (temps ~36°F but windchills in the upper 20s, with periods of moderate rain). If pavement temps dip or slush/leftover snow exists on edges, brief glazing can occur even when air temp is just above freezing.

Ask building/grounds crews to prioritize: bus loop, parent drop-off, and main sidewalks for standing water and slick-film risk; cone/close any known puddle zones that routinely refreeze or hide potholes.

Bus ops: run normal routes but plan for slightly longer stopping distances during the 6:30–8:00 AM window; emphasize smooth braking and wider turns. Consider allowing buses to run 5–10 minutes earlier if staffing allows.
Parent/staff messaging: 'Wet roads + near-freezing temps' reminder; slow down on bridges, ramps, and neighborhood streets; watch for fog/low visibility pockets early.
Decision guidance: this setup is much more likely to produce a delay than a closure, and even a delay would depend on observed slick spots (not predicted snow).

local_news.headline: Ahead of the Ice: Kent County Road Commission preps for anticipated icy roads
local_news.summary: KCRC says roads are dry now but expects potentially challenging travel with icing; plans include pre-treating bridge decks with liquid, staffing ~90 drivers starting ~4 a.m. Thursday, and using salt/sand abrasives depending on conditions. While this story is focused on the Wed night/Thu window, it’s a strong signal that West Michigan is in an ‘ice setup’ pattern during the Wed–Thu period that can influence Wednesday (2/18) school decisions if icing arrives earlier than expected.

local_news.summary: FOX 17 reported slick roads for the Tuesday morning commute after rain/snow the prior night, with multiple delays/cancellations posted for that morning. This is relevant as ‘momentum’—if conditions worsen into Wednesday, districts sometimes escalate from delays to closure.

The limiting factor for a school closure would be flooding/ice-jam-related localized impacts rather than snow-covered roads.

webWeatherVerifier.verification_summary: For Rockford, MI (Wed 2026-02-18), WeatherAPI’s key school-commute window (6–9 AM) shows temps ~36–38°F with ‘feels like’ about 27–29°F and rain (not snow). Also note WeatherAPI has an NWS Grand Rapids Hydrologic Outlook (river rises/ice jam potential), which typically does not drive same-day school closures but indicates broader melt/rain impacts.

primary_factors: Forecast is rain (not snow) with air temps staying above freezing around bus/commute time (mid-30s °F); no accumulating snow/ice signal

final.decision_rationale:
All six inputs converge on a mild, wet system for Rockford with temperatures above freezing and zero snowfall expected—this is typically an ‘open’ day in Michigan. The only credible pathway to disruption is a narrow-margin surface-temperature issue: if bridge decks/untreated elevated surfaces briefly reach ~32°F while rain is occurring (or immediately after), isolated glazing/black-ice spots could appear, especially on rural routes and overpasses. That scenario historically drives targeted spot-treating and sometimes a 2-hour delay, but it rarely produces a district-wide closure without a clear freezing-rain headline or widespread subfreezing conditions.

There are no “domino effect” signals: the latest available checks show no active closings/delays on FOX17, no Rockford announcement, and no neighboring-district postings. Infrastructure capability is normal/ready (spot-treatment likely if needed), and power-grid status is stable (Kent County ~0% out). Given the strong consensus (agents within ~2% spread) and the lack of leading closure indicators, the Brier-score-optimized call is a low single-digit-to-high single-digit closure probability.

Recommendation: **Open with monitoring** (not a snow day). If anything changes, it’s more likely to be a **2-hour delay** than a full closure, driven by observed slick bridges or localized flooding/ice-jam detours—not snow accumulation.

positions.rationale: For Rockford, MI on Wednesday 2026-02-18, the forecast is a mild/wet system with moderate rain and temperatures holding just above freezing during the school-commute window. With no snowfall forecast and no subfreezing air temperature period indicated, the probability of a true ‘snow day’ (district-wide closure due to winter conditions) is very low. The only plausible pathway to a higher closure probability would be an unforecast temperature drop of a couple degrees that turns rain into a brief freezing-rain glaze on bridges/overpasses and untreated rural segments right around 6–8 AM; given the current hourly guidance keeps air temps ~36°F, I treat that as a low-probability tail risk rather than the base case.
keyFactors: Thermal profile strongly favors rain: forecast temps stay above freezing all day (low ~35°F, 6–9 AM ~36–38°F), with 0" snow and 0% snow chance—so the classic snow-day trigger (accumulating snow during bus window) is absent.

Primary precip impact is moderate rain concentrated near the commute window (roughly 4–6 AM and again near ~8 AM) with ~0.77" liquid. That can slow travel (ponding/splash, reduced traction on wet pavement) but typically doesn’t close West Michigan schools by itself.
Wind is breezy but not disruptive (max ~18 mph; gusts ~25–28 mph). This won’t create blizzard/drifting, and it’s below common wind-related closure thresholds.

Visibility: brief lower vis is possible (notably ~1 mile around 1 AM in the hourly data, plus low clouds/fog mention). That’s more “delay potential” than “closure potential,” and the worst low-vis signal is not squarely in the 6–8 AM decision window.
Hydrologic Outlook highlights river rises/ice movement/ice-jam potential. That’s a localized impact risk (specific low spots, isolated detours) rather than a widespread school-closure driver.

positions.rationale: As the history specialist, I anchor on how often Rockford/greater Kent County districts close for *non-snow* winter weather. The forecast for Wednesday 2026-02-18 is a classic thaw-and-rain day (high ~48°F, morning mid/upper-30s) with moderate rain near the commute. That pattern typically yields wet roads and occasional fog/ponding, not a snow day. The only credible closure pathway is a narrow one: temperatures verifying a few degrees colder on elevated/low-traffic surfaces causing freezing rain/glaze or a brief flash-freeze—more consistent with a delay than a closure. Given peers (meteorology at ~0–5% closure risk; safety calling ice risk ‘moderate’ but still emphasizing delay>closure), I set a low but non-zero cancellation probability.
keyFactors: Forecast signal is overwhelmingly *rain* (≈0.77" liquid) with *0" snow*; historically in West Michigan, rain-only mid-winter events rarely trigger full closures unless they produce widespread icing or impassable flooding.

Temperatures during the decision window (roughly 6–9 AM Wed 2026-02-18) are forecast around 36–38°F—above freezing—so the most common closure mechanism (accumulating snow) is absent and the second most common (meaningful ice accretion) is not supported by the point forecast.

The one historical “gotcha” pattern is a *small cold bias* (e.g., actual 31–33°F on bridge decks/untreated back roads) that turns rain into patchy glaze right at bus time; that pathway is plausible but usually produces *delays* more often than full cancellations.

Hydrologic Outlook (snowmelt + rain; river rises/possible ice movement) supports ponding/isolated trouble spots, but historically these are too localized to drive district-wide closures unless a specific route/network gets cut off.
Public/operational signals lean “normal ops”: no early closure banner found; live closings page showed none at time checked; road agencies appear in “prep” mode rather than “event already underway.”

positions.rationale: From a news/operations perspective, the strongest leading indicators for a next-day closure are: (1) official district pre-announcements, (2) widespread neighboring-district actions, and (3) clear, high-impact NWS winter headlines (advisory/warning) that local outlets amplify. None of those are present in the shared intel. Instead, we have a mild-temperature, rain-dominant forecast and a hydrologic outlook (monitoring rivers/ice jams) that typically does not prompt same-day school closure decisions. The only pathway to a surprise closure is if the rain overlaps subfreezing road-surface temps (bridges/overpasses/back roads) right in the 6–8 AM decision window, creating widespread slickness beyond what treatment can handle. Given the absence of early closure postings and the rain/above-freezing air temps, I keep the closure probability low, but not zero.

No sustained subfreezing air temps are indicated (freezing hours = 0), which sharply limits widespread icing potential and makes a plow/treatment-driven closure unlikely.

Main impact window is pre-dawn into early morning with moderate rain bursts (notably ~4–6 AM and again near ~8 AM) that can slow travel via ponding and reduced visibility, but usually produces delays at most.
Wind/gusts (sustained ~10–18 mph, gusts ~30–45 mph) are below typical “blowing snow/whiteout” or outage-driving thresholds; not a classic closure driver.
Non-winter hazard signal exists (Hydrologic Outlook: rises/ice movement/ice jam possibility). This can create very localized issues but rarely causes district-wide closure on its own.

Tail risk: small negative temperature error (2–4°F) + high precip rates could flip to brief freezing rain on elevated/untreated surfaces (bridges/overpasses/rural routes) right at bus time; this is the main reason probability is non-zero.

positions.rationale: Relative to my Round-1 4%, I’m nudging up slightly to 6% because (a) the precip is heavy for February and timed near commute, and (b) multiple analyses flag near-freezing ‘feels like’ and a non-trivial chance of isolated slick bridges. Still, the dominant historical analog here is ‘winter thaw + rain’ leading to slower travel and occasional delays, not a widespread closure—especially with temps staying above freezing and no snow forecast. Net: low probability of a true snow day/closure, with the more likely disruption mode being a delay if slick spots are observed at daybreak.
keyFactors: Historical base rate: In Rockford/Kent County, full-day closures are overwhelmingly tied to accumulating snow/whiteout or significant ice accretion—not to 35–40°F rain events.

Forecast profile for Wed 2026-02-18: ~0.77" rain with air temps around the commute near 36°F and then warming into the 40s. That pattern historically produces ‘wet/sloppy’ travel and, at most, a delay—especially given strong winter operations capacity in West Michigan.

Tail-risk pathway (the only meaningful one): a small temp/road-surface error (bridges/overpasses/back roads at/just below 32°F) during the 6–8 AM decision window could create patchy glaze from heavy rain rates. That can elevate incident rates enough for a conservative district to delay/cancel, but it’s usually localized and short-lived.

Hydrologic Outlook context: snowmelt + rain can cause ponding and very localized flooding/ice-jam issues, but historically this is rarely a district-wide closure trigger unless a known low-lying route becomes impassable across a wide portion of the district.

positions.rationale: As the safety specialist, I’m weighting *transport risk during the decision window* (roughly 05:30–08:30 on Wednesday, Feb 18, 2026) rather than the label “snow day.” The forecast supports a wet commute with some reduced visibility and ponding, but not widespread impassable roads. The main safety wildcard is a small downward temperature error that turns “wet” into “patchy ice” on elevated/untreated surfaces; that scenario more commonly drives a **delay** than a full closure. Given Michigan districts’ winter operations and the lack of accumulating snow/ice signal, I place closure probability in the high-single-digits rather than the 40% I’d reserve for clear, widespread icing or heavy snow.
keyFactors: Forecast is rain-dominant with 0" snow expected; air temps hover in the mid-30s to upper-40s, which is usually not closure-producing in West Michigan.

The highest-impact window is pre-dawn through mid-morning (about 04:00–09:00) with bursts of moderate rain near typical bus/arrival time; this increases crash risk via hydroplaning/longer stopping distances rather than snow obstruction.

Near-freezing *surface* risk is the only real escalation path: windchills in the upper 20s with air temps ~36°F means bridge decks/overpasses/shaded rural segments could flirt with freezing, allowing isolated glazing if temps verify a couple degrees colder or if residual slush exists at road edges.
Visibility is a secondary safety concern (fog/low clouds noted; low vis pockets increase bus/teen-driver risk) but the forecast does not indicate widespread dense fog at peak commute.

Hydrologic Outlook suggests melt + rain and possible ice movement/ice jams; that can create very localized water-over-road issues, but it’s unlikely to be district-wide or timed to force a full closure.

positions.rationale:
From a NEWS/decision-signals lens, I stay low because the typical leading indicators for a next-day closure aren’t present: there’s no official district pre-announcement, no visible wave of neighboring-district actions, and no prominent winter-storm headline being echoed. The forecast is primarily moderate rain with air temps hovering just above freezing at daybreak (Wed 2026-02-18), which usually yields “wet commute + maybe a delay,” not a full closure.

I’m nudging my Round-1 4% up to **6%** only to account for the “ice setup” messaging from the Kent County Road Commission and the narrow-temp-margin risk (if conditions arrive earlier/colder than modeled, decision-makers sometimes flip quickly before dawn).
keyFactors: **Public/operational signals are quiet**: No Rockford Public Schools closure/delay messaging found and FOX 17’s closings page showed no active closings at last check—this usually correlates with “normal open” for the next school day.

**No winter headline being amplified**: The only NWS product in the data is a *Hydrologic Outlook* (river rises/ice jams), not a Winter Weather Advisory/Warning—media + district ops typically react much more strongly to the latter.

**Forecast narrative is rain + above-freezing air temps**: Broadly consistent across the provided WeatherAPI and the web-verifier summary (no snow, temps mid-30s to 40s). That’s not a classic closure trigger in West Michigan.

**Tail risk = early-morning glaze/visibility**: Heavy rain bursts around the bus/commute window plus wind-chill in the upper 20s means bridges/overpasses/back roads could briefly go slick if temps verify a couple degrees colder than forecast; fog/low vis pockets could also push *delays*.

debates.topic: 40% closure risk appears too high given the provided hourly air temps are above freezing and the precip type is forecast as rain with 0 snow. If your score is really capturing ‘delay or major travel disruption’ rather than ‘closure,’ we should separate those outcomes; otherwise the meteorological forcing doesn’t support a near-coin-flip closure.

debates.topic: Local reporting about ‘anticipated icy roads’ seems focused on the Wed night/Thu window; we should be careful not to import Thursday’s icing risk into Wednesday morning unless there’s evidence onset is earlier than forecast (e.g., subfreezing obs/nowcasts by pre-dawn Wed).

confidenceJourney.shiftReason: Compared with Round 1 (3%), I’m nudging up slightly to 6% mainly to acknowledge the peer safety concern and the broader regional “ice setup” messaging (road commission preparing for icing later in the Wed–Thu period). Meteorologically, the base case remains: a mild, wet system with air temps above freezing during the decision window and no accumulating snow. That points to school being open. The only plausible closure pathway is not snow, but a surprise freezing-rain glaze/patchy black ice if temps verify a few degrees colder than forecast on bridges/back roads while moderate rain is occurring near 6–8 AM. Even then, history suggests a delay is more likely than a full closure. Therefore, district-wide closure probability stays low but non-zero.

Relative to my Round-1 4%, I’m nudging up slightly to 6% because (a) the precip is heavy for February and timed near commute, and (b) multiple analyses flag near-freezing ‘feels like’ and a non-trivial chance of isolated slick bridges. Still, the dominant historical analog here is ‘winter thaw + rain’ leading to slower travel and occasional delays, not a widespread closure—especially with temps staying above freezing and no snow forecast. Net: low probability of a true snow day/closure, with the more likely disruption mode being a delay if slick spots are observed at daybreak.

As the safety specialist, I’m weighting *transport risk during the decision window* (roughly 05:30–08:30 on Wednesday, Feb 18, 2026) rather than the label “snow day.” The forecast supports a wet commute with some reduced visibility and ponding, but not widespread impassable roads. The main safety wildcard is a small downward temperature error that turns “wet” into “patchy ice” on elevated/untreated surfaces; that scenario more commonly drives a **delay** than a full closure. Given Michigan districts’ winter operations and the lack of accumulating snow/ice signal, I place closure probability in the high-single-digits rather than the 40% I’d reserve for clear, widespread icing or heavy snow.

From a NEWS/decision-signals lens, I stay low because the typical leading indicators for a next-day closure aren’t present: there’s no official district pre-announcement, no visible wave of neighboring-district actions, and no prominent winter-storm headline being echoed. The forecast is primarily moderate rain with air temps hovering just above freezing at daybreak (Wed 2026-02-18), which usually yields “wet commute + maybe a delay,” not a full closure.

I’m nudging my Round-1 4% up to **6%** only to account for the “ice setup” messaging from the Kent County Road Commission and the narrow-temp-margin risk (if conditions arrive earlier/colder than modeled, decision-makers sometimes flip quickly before dawn).

keyDisagreements.topic: You rate ice-formation risk as ‘moderate.’ From a meteorology standpoint, with air temps forecast ~36–38°F at bus time and no modeled freezing precip, I’d downgrade widespread icing risk to low-to-occasionally-moderate (bridge decks/isolated cold pockets only). If you have pavement-temp or obs-based justification, call it out explicitly because that’s the main uncertainty lever here.

alert.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued February 17 at 9:43AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Allegan, MI; Barry, MI; Calhoun, MI; Clinton, MI; Eaton, MI; Ingham, MI; Ionia, MI; Jackson, MI; Kalamazoo, MI; Kent, MI; Muskegon, MI; Ottawa, MI; Van Buren, MI
alert.desc:
ESFGRR

Steady melting of snow and ice over the last week has begun to cause
rivers to rise across the area. Several chances for rain this week
will add to these rises. Based on current expected rainfall, no
significant flooding is expected on West Michigan rivers, though
typical spring water level rises within the river channels will
happen.

Meanwhile, river ice has weakened significantly over the last week,
and as water levels rise any remaining ice will likely be broken and
start to move downstream. This creates the possibility for formation
of a few ice jams. Ice jams tend to form in the same places
repeatedly, so special attention should be paid in the Comstock Park
(Kent County) area as well as the Robinson Township (Ottawa County)
area along the Grand River.

Anyone living or working near West Michigan rivers should pay extra
attention this week as water levels rise. Have a plan to monitor and
respond if flooding develops unexpectedly.

Monitor the latest conditions at https://water.noaa.gov
